Drew: Both players scored {{playerPoints}} out of possible 120 points and drew the game.

Help_text_1: Briscola is played with a standard Italian deck of cards. It consists of forty cards, divided into four suits: Clubs (Denari), Diamonds (Spade), Spade (Coppe) and Clubs (Bastoni).
Help_text_2: Below are the cards from the
Help_text_3: suit with their names and point values, in order from weakest to strongest. Note the odd ranking of the three.
Help_text_4: The game of Instant Briscola begins as soon as two players are in the lobby. The deck is shuffled and each player is dealt three cards. The seventh card from the deck is the briscola - It represents the trump suit for the game and it's placed face up on the board. The remainder of the deck is placed face down next to the briscola card and players will draw cards from it throughout the game.
Help_text_5: In the Instant Briscola the player who created the lobby leads the first trick by playing one of his cards face up on the board. The opponent then responds with a card of his own and the played cards are compared at this point.
Help_text_6:
The winner of the trick is determined as follows:
- If only one player played a briscola, he wins no matter what card the opponent played
- If both players played a card of the same suit ( briscola or any other suit), the winner is determined by comparing the strength of the played cards
- If neither player played a briscola card and the played cards are not of the same suit, the player who was the first to play in the trick wins it
Help_text_7: (Keep in mind that in Briscola, players are not required to follow suit, that is, to play the same suit as the lead player.)
Help_text_8: The winner of the trick pockets both played cards and is dealt a new card from the top of the shuffled deck. The loser of the trick receives the next card from the deck and we enter the next trick where the winner of the last trick plays the first card. The play proceeds in this manner until the deck is empty. Note that the last card collected in the game should be the up-turned briscola. The fact that the briscola is now in the hand of one of the players does not change anything about the trump suit of the game and we proceed with playing until all forty cards are collected from the board. It is time to calculate the total point value of cards each player acquired and determine the winner. Since there is a total of 120 points in the full Briscola deck, the player who collected at least 61 points wins the game.
Help_text_9: If both players agree to a rematch, their positions are switched and a new game begins.
